Intro.610: On Tuesday, a new type of malware was discovered that targets Apple’s Mac OS X. Called Crisis, the Trojan creates a backdoor on an infected Mac as long as it runs OS X version 10.6 or 10.7.  [Read More]
Intro.611: If allowed to run, a malicious Java applet checks the user's operating system and delivers a payload customized for that platform, whether it's Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux.  [Read More]
Intro.612: Researchers from Russian security firm Kaspersky Lab today said they have discovered a new APT campaign that is using a new Mac OS X backdoor variant targeted at Uyghur activists.  [Read More]
Intro.613: Version 11.3 of Adobe’s Flash Player, due in June, will provide the same silent update feature currently available to Windows users to those running OS X. In addition, Adobe will also offer a new security enhancement to Firefox called protected mode.  [Read More]
Intro.614: Microsoft researchers have discovered new malware targeting the Mac, but unlike Flashback, this one is targeting a flaw in Office for Mac that was patched years ago.  [Read More]
Intro.615: Once SabPub is installed on a Mac, it will connect to a C&C and wait for instructions. To have a look at what happens after, Kaspersky installed SabPub on a test system and let it run.  [Read More]
Intro.616: The malware, known as SabPub, has been spotted spreading through malicious Microsoft Word documents exploiting the same Java vulnerability targeted by the now-notorious Flashback Trojan.  [Read More]
Intro.617: Security researchers at Kaspersky Lab and Intego have released free tools to help Mac users infected with the Flashback Trojan clean their computers.  [Read More]
Intro.618: Security researchers say the Flashback malware hitting Mac OS X machines has built a powerful botnet of more than 550,000 computers.  [Read More]
Intro.619: If exploited, the Mac malware could drop additional malicious payloads, or modify targeted websites in order to bombard a user with annoying ads – which earn money for the attackers.  [Read More]
Intro.620: The Trojan, named “Mac Control” by its authors, executes when the system starts, and will established a connection to the C&C in order to wait for commands. Investigation into the malware itself shows it has the ability to allow remote shells, as well as the ability to send, receive, and delete files.  [Read More]
Intro.621: On Friday, Intego reported that a new variant of Flashback is targeting passwords and as a byproduct of infection, Flashback is crashing several notable applications.  [Read More]
Intro.622: A Trojan targeting Mac OS X, named Flashback by some vendors, is disabling the XProtect component of Apple’s operating system. The latest variant of the Fashback will disable XProtect’s automatic update features, preventing new detections from being installed to the infected host.  [Read More]
Intro.623: The specter of advanced persistent threats (APTs) hangs over a growing number of conversations these days about enterprise security, and has prompted businesses to take a closer look at how they can make their environments less vulnerable. For some, this has reignited discussions about how the security of Apple’s Mac OS X stacks up against Microsoft Windows.  [Read More]
Intro.624: AVG Technologies today announced an offering for Mac lovers. AVG LinkScanner for Mac...  [Read More]
Intro.625: New attack method can be used to track mobile devices that rely on MAC address randomization to protect privacy  [Read More]
Intro.626: Another fake bank notification spam has been spotted by our engineers and the sample we caught is a typical example of such email-based threats. The body of the letter, designed to mimic an official notification from a very popular bank in Britain, urgently tells the reader to check the attached file in order to verify 'terms and conditions', most likely for the purpose of a business transaction.Read more
Intro.627: We recently encountered a spam sample that purports itself to be a purchase order from IKEA, which is a famous furniture retailer founded in Sweden and features modern Scandanavian furniture. However, once unsuspecting users or legitimate IKEA customers open the attached .Read more
Intro.628: Users may find e-mails coming from a known antivirus company nothing to be surprised about, but alarms should definitely start ringing when the antivirus company mailing you isn't the one you're subscribed to - and that their mails are festooned with links to websites peddling Viagra.Our team of engineers recently found a spam mail making the rounds, masking itself as a legit mail coming from CA Technologies.Read more
Intro.629: In a bid to get users to click, cybercriminals turn to your trusted persons. We have seen spammed messages with vCard attachments, electronic business cards that contain personal information of a person such as name, address, phone number, email address, website and even audio clips.Read more
Intro.630: Pharmaceutical spam isn't necessarily a malicious type of spam, but there exists the potential for them to lead to malicious or scam sites, so we always advise users to keep clear of them. This time is no different, as we spotted a new batch of samples that purported themselves to be urgent notifications from sites of general interest, such as Facebook, Youtube and Instagram.Read more
Intro.631: Cybercriminals will always capitalize on the popular and the trusted, and this latest pharmacy spam campaign is no exception. In fact, it proves the theory in spades, as not only does it spoof popular social networking website email notifications such as Facebook and Instagram, it also spoofs iTunes, Google and Fedex! The mails, while obviously different in terms of which website they're spoofing, all link to the same online pharmacy website, one that seems to specialize in performance enhancement drugs.Read more
Intro.632: Trend Micro researchers spotted another spammed email messages purporting to be from popular social networking sites LinkedIn and MySpace. The mail from LinkedIn asks the users to click on a provided link in order to confirm their email address.Read more
Intro.633: A spammed message promoting something called the Google Accredited Pharmacy is seen in the wild. The said email message contains an image that shows a link.Read more
Intro.634: With Valentine's Day just around the corner, spammers are leveraging this event to lure users into fake online pharmacy websites. The bogus sites promote Valentine's day special offers on pharmacy-related products.Read more
Intro.635: Trend Micro uncovered bulk samples of spam that sell pharmaceutical products. The message is written in both French and English.Read more
Intro.636: Holiday-themed threats are a staple in today's threat landscape. In particular, users should be on the lookout for spammed messages that leverage popular events.Read more
Intro.637: Spammers are now leveraging popular website, Wikipedia to point users to pharmacy sites. TrendLabs engineers spotted spammed messages in plain text that contained a URL.Read more
Intro.638: Cybercriminals always capitalize on current events as well as holidays. Just recently, TrendLabs researchers spotted spammed messages that bore the subject, 'Delivery within USA 2-3 day !!.Read more

Intro.663: A new cryptocurrency-mining malware was uncovered targeting macOS systems: — OSX.CreativeUpdate Here's what you need to know.
Intro.664: Due to BEC’s evolving and treacherous nature, run-of-the-mill best practices and security solutions have become weak to withstand attacks. Find out how advanced solutions that utilize artificial intelligence and machine learning help in defending against BEC.
Intro.665: Security researchers uncovered a multi-stage attack chain that takes advantage of a design behavior in RTF files and a vulnerability in Microsoft Office (CVE-2017-8570) to deliver the Formbook RAT.
Intro.666: A new cryptocurrency-mining malware was uncovered targeting macOS systems: — OSX.CreativeUpdate Here's what you need to know.
Intro.667: Two remote access Trojans targeting Mac users are making headlines: Snake and Proton. Know more about their malicious tricks and how to mitigate them.
Intro.668: A MacOS ransomware, a disguised Venus Locker variant and other notable ransomware stories from February 16-24, 2017.

Intro.746: Mac security firm Intego has discovered a new type of malware for OS X, which will pose a bit of a problem when it comes to protection, given its use of Open SSH.  [Read More]
Intro.747: Researchers have observed a recent spike in attacks against the Uyghur community to monitor their email and chat activities, according AlientVault and Kaspersky Lab.  [Read More]
Intro.748: Tibetan activists are being targeted by a new variant of the Imuler (Revir) Trojan that was discovered in September. The attack is launched via email, and uses images of other pro-Tibetan groups as bait in order to encourage the victim into opening files.  [Read More]
Intro.749: Anti-Virus firm Dr. Web has discovered another family of Mac-based malware that targets passwords. In addition to Mac OS X, this malware also targets Linux installations.  [Read More]
Intro.750: Symantec malware researchers discovered that the JAR file that is used by Crisis to infect a given system has an additional payload for Windows, and may be the first malware that attempts to spread onto a virtual machine.  [Read More]
Intro.751: New features in the Alpha++ release of CrowdRE include Linux and Mac versions of the plugin, as well as granular sharing controls and "Karma" ratings within the platform.  [Read More]
Intro.752: ThreatMetrix, published a report on the Crisis Trojan that breaks the code down, and examines the internals of the latest threat targeting Mac OS X users.  [Read More]
Intro.753: On Tuesday, a new type of malware was discovered that targets Apple’s Mac OS X. Called Crisis, the Trojan creates a backdoor on an infected Mac as long as it runs OS X version 10.6 or 10.7.  [Read More]
Intro.754: If allowed to run, a malicious Java applet checks the user's operating system and delivers a payload customized for that platform, whether it's Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux.  [Read More]
Intro.755: Researchers from Russian security firm Kaspersky Lab today said they have discovered a new APT campaign that is using a new Mac OS X backdoor variant targeted at Uyghur activists.  [Read More]
Intro.756: Version 11.3 of Adobe’s Flash Player, due in June, will provide the same silent update feature currently available to Windows users to those running OS X. In addition, Adobe will also offer a new security enhancement to Firefox called protected mode.  [Read More]
Intro.757: Microsoft researchers have discovered new malware targeting the Mac, but unlike Flashback, this one is targeting a flaw in Office for Mac that was patched years ago.  [Read More]
Intro.758: Once SabPub is installed on a Mac, it will connect to a C&C and wait for instructions. To have a look at what happens after, Kaspersky installed SabPub on a test system and let it run.  [Read More]
Intro.759: The malware, known as SabPub, has been spotted spreading through malicious Microsoft Word documents exploiting the same Java vulnerability targeted by the now-notorious Flashback Trojan.  [Read More]
Intro.760: Security researchers at Kaspersky Lab and Intego have released free tools to help Mac users infected with the Flashback Trojan clean their computers.  [Read More]
Intro.761: Security researchers say the Flashback malware hitting Mac OS X machines has built a powerful botnet of more than 550,000 computers.  [Read More]
Intro.762: If exploited, the Mac malware could drop additional malicious payloads, or modify targeted websites in order to bombard a user with annoying ads – which earn money for the attackers.  [Read More]
Intro.763: The Trojan, named “Mac Control” by its authors, executes when the system starts, and will established a connection to the C&C in order to wait for commands. Investigation into the malware itself shows it has the ability to allow remote shells, as well as the ability to send, receive, and delete files.  [Read More]
Intro.764: On Friday, Intego reported that a new variant of Flashback is targeting passwords and as a byproduct of infection, Flashback is crashing several notable applications.  [Read More]
Intro.765: A Trojan targeting Mac OS X, named Flashback by some vendors, is disabling the XProtect component of Apple’s operating system. The latest variant of the Fashback will disable XProtect’s automatic update features, preventing new detections from being installed to the infected host.  [Read More]
Intro.766: The specter of advanced persistent threats (APTs) hangs over a growing number of conversations these days about enterprise security, and has prompted businesses to take a closer look at how they can make their environments less vulnerable. For some, this has reignited discussions about how the security of Apple’s Mac OS X stacks up against Microsoft Windows.  [Read More]
Intro.767: AVG Technologies today announced an offering for Mac lovers. AVG LinkScanner for Mac...  [Read More]
Intro.768: New attack method can be used to track mobile devices that rely on MAC address randomization to protect privacy  [Read More]
Intro.769: Another fake bank notification spam has been spotted by our engineers and the sample we caught is a typical example of such email-based threats. The body of the letter, designed to mimic an official notification from a very popular bank in Britain, urgently tells the reader to check the attached file in order to verify 'terms and conditions', most likely for the purpose of a business transaction.Read more
Intro.770: We recently encountered a spam sample that purports itself to be a purchase order from IKEA, which is a famous furniture retailer founded in Sweden and features modern Scandanavian furniture. However, once unsuspecting users or legitimate IKEA customers open the attached .Read more
Intro.771: Users may find e-mails coming from a known antivirus company nothing to be surprised about, but alarms should definitely start ringing when the antivirus company mailing you isn't the one you're subscribed to - and that their mails are festooned with links to websites peddling Viagra.Our team of engineers recently found a spam mail making the rounds, masking itself as a legit mail coming from CA Technologies.Read more
Intro.772: In a bid to get users to click, cybercriminals turn to your trusted persons. We have seen spammed messages with vCard attachments, electronic business cards that contain personal information of a person such as name, address, phone number, email address, website and even audio clips.Read more
Intro.773: Pharmaceutical spam isn't necessarily a malicious type of spam, but there exists the potential for them to lead to malicious or scam sites, so we always advise users to keep clear of them. This time is no different, as we spotted a new batch of samples that purported themselves to be urgent notifications from sites of general interest, such as Facebook, Youtube and Instagram.Read more
Intro.774: Cybercriminals will always capitalize on the popular and the trusted, and this latest pharmacy spam campaign is no exception. In fact, it proves the theory in spades, as not only does it spoof popular social networking website email notifications such as Facebook and Instagram, it also spoofs iTunes, Google and Fedex! The mails, while obviously different in terms of which website they're spoofing, all link to the same online pharmacy website, one that seems to specialize in performance enhancement drugs.Read more
Intro.775: Trend Micro researchers spotted another spammed email messages purporting to be from popular social networking sites LinkedIn and MySpace. The mail from LinkedIn asks the users to click on a provided link in order to confirm their email address.Read more
Intro.776: A spammed message promoting something called the Google Accredited Pharmacy is seen in the wild. The said email message contains an image that shows a link.Read more
Intro.777: With Valentine's Day just around the corner, spammers are leveraging this event to lure users into fake online pharmacy websites. The bogus sites promote Valentine's day special offers on pharmacy-related products.Read more
Intro.778: Trend Micro uncovered bulk samples of spam that sell pharmaceutical products. The message is written in both French and English.Read more
Intro.779: Holiday-themed threats are a staple in today's threat landscape. In particular, users should be on the lookout for spammed messages that leverage popular events.Read more
Intro.780: Spammers are now leveraging popular website, Wikipedia to point users to pharmacy sites. TrendLabs engineers spotted spammed messages in plain text that contained a URL.Read more
Intro.781: Cybercriminals always capitalize on current events as well as holidays. Just recently, TrendLabs researchers spotted spammed messages that bore the subject, 'Delivery within USA 2-3 day !!.Read more

Intro.817: Two remote access Trojans targeting Mac users are making headlines: Snake and Proton. Know more about their malicious tricks and how to mitigate them.
Intro.818: A MacOS ransomware, a disguised Venus Locker variant and other notable ransomware stories from February 16-24, 2017.
Intro.819: Cybercriminals known as the Skimer Group are reusing the malware they created to target ATMs seven years ago—posing a more sophisticated and advanced threat to banks and customers around the globe.
Intro.820: Microsoft is rolling out Office 2016 with an anti-macro malware feature. We tell you all about it and how to activate it.

Intro.823: SMBs accounted for 45% of all incidents involving PoS malware in Q3 2015, but malware isn't the only thing that retailers have to worry about. PoS machines can be compromised even before they get installed.
Intro.824: It's been 20 years since the first macro malware was discovered in 1995. Here's how it evolved through the years.
Intro.825: Last month, a Latin American organized crime gang hacked over 14 ATMs in Malaysia, pilfering an estimated RM3mil (almost $1 million USD). While the incident only affected the banks that were hit, there are other threats that target ATM users as well.
Intro.826: Right on the heels of the Shellshock comes another threat that targets Mac users. Known as iWORM, this malware connects to a C&C; server, allowing it to perform actions ranging from information theft and file downloads to configuration changes.
Intro.827: Who did hack Macron? The obvious conclusion is Russia; because Russia would benefit most from a Le Pen victory. But the timing of the document leaks was far too late to benefit Le Pen, and would more likely benefit Macron.  [Read More]

Intro.829: Russia-linked Turla cyberspies are apparently working on developing a Mac OS X version of their Snake malware  [Read More]
Intro.830: Machete cyberespionage group continues to target organizations in Spanish-speaking and other countries  [Read More]

Intro.832: Cyber espionage group linked to Iran uses Mac malware named MacDownloader to steal data from infected devices  [Read More]
Intro.833: Cybercriminals have been serving malicious advertisements on several high-profile websites in an effort to push shady software onto the computers of their visitors, regardless if they are Windows or OS X users, Cisco reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.834: The malware at the center of the 'Machete' cyber attacks is capable of a number of actions, including logging keystrokes, capturing audio and screenshots, taking photos from the victim's webcam and capturing geo-location data.  [Read More]
Intro.835: A variant of the Dok malware for Mac targets Swiss banking users in attacks that appear to be part of Operation Emmental  [Read More]
Intro.836: A malicious RTF (Rich Text Format) document has been persistently displaying an alert asking users to enable macros, Zscaler security researchers have discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.837: A malicious attack uses a multi-stage infection to deploy a tool capable of stealing passwords from various applications on the victim’s computer, Trustwave reports.  [Read More]
Intro.838: Maliciously modified copies of popular applications distributed via the MacUpdate site were observed installing crypto-mining malware on the users’ Macs.  [Read More]
Intro.839: Focused on mining Monero crypto-currency, a new botnet has managed to ensnare over half a million machines to date, most of which are believed to be servers.  [Read More]
Intro.840: MaMi is a new piece of malware designed to hijack DNS settings on infected macOS machines. Other capabilities present, but not active  [Read More]
Intro.841: An Ohio man was charged this week in a 16-count indictment for allegedly developing malware known as “FruitFly” and for infecting thousands of computers with it.  [Read More]
Intro.842: In an effort to boost the fight against malicious software, anti-malware company Avast this week announced the release of its retargetable machine-code decompiler as open source.  [Read More]
Intro.843: macOS-targeting HiddenLotus backdoor is using an innovative technique to disguise the fact that it is an executable in order to avoid alerting users on its execution.  [Read More]
Intro.844: A newly observed variant of the macOS-targeting Proton malware is spreading through a blog spoofing that of legitimate security company Symantec.  [Read More]
Intro.845: Hackers breach Eltima website and use it to deliver macOS RAT Proton via a trojanized version of Elmedia Player  [Read More]
Intro.846: Recently observed distribution campaigns featuring the Ursnif banking Trojan were using new malicious macro tactics for payload delivery  [Read More]
Intro.847: WikiLeaks publishes documents describing three tools used by the CIA to hack OS X and other POSIX systems  [Read More]
Intro.848: A news website in Georgia delivers a new version of the old Mac Trojan dubbed Leverage to Safari users  [Read More]
Intro.849: A variant of the Dok malware for Mac targets Swiss banking users in attacks that appear to be part of Operation Emmental  [Read More]
Intro.850: Hot on the heels of MacRansom Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) comes the first malware-as-a-service (MaaS) targeting Mac users, offered for prices starting as low as free, AlienVault reveals.  [Read More]
Intro.851: MacRansom is a newly discovered ransomware family targeting Mac users is using the Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) distribution model and uses code copied from previous MacOS ransomware, Fortinet researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.852: Trend Micro has published details on a spam campaign it detected in late May that delivers malware by using PowerPoint files and mouseover events.  [Read More]
Intro.853: A download mirror for the video converting tool HandBrake was recently compromised and configured to distribute a remote administration Trojan (RAT) for Mac computers.  [Read More]
Intro.854: The Cerber ransomware is using new evasion techniques designed elude machine learning security solutions.  [Read More]
Intro.855: Cybercriminals have been using a macro-enabled Word document that can be used to infect both macOS and Windows machines with malware.  [Read More]
Intro.856: macOS users who had their systems infected with the FindZip ransomware can now use a decryption tool to restore their files without paying the ransom.  [Read More]
Intro.857: A new remote access tool (RAT) targeting macOS machines currently advertised on underground markets is believed to be using an unpatched 0-day vulnerability to gain root access on target machines.  [Read More]
Intro.858: Filecoder is a newly discovered ransomware targeting macOS that destroys encryption keys before sending them to its apparently inexperienced developer.  [Read More]
Intro.859: Russia-linked threat group APT28 (aka Pawn Storm, Fancy Bear and Sofacy) created a Mac version of its X-Agent Trojan  [Read More]
Intro.860: A recently discovered Microsoft Office loader uses malicious macros to drop multiple malware families, Palo Alto Networks security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.861: Malware that abuses macro-enabled Microsoft Office documents to spread is now targeting macOS users too.  [Read More]
Intro.862: Cyber espionage group linked to Iran uses Mac malware named MacDownloader to steal data from infected devices  [Read More]
Intro.863: Newly discovered Quimitchin malware has been found infecting Mac OS X systems, in what security experts consider to be "the first Mac malware of 2017."  [Read More]
Intro.864: Malware designed to crash Mac OS machines is being delivered through drive-by downloads as part of a campaign designed to trick users into calling a fake tech support service.  [Read More]

Intro.917: AVG Technologies today announced an offering for Mac lovers. AVG LinkScanner for Mac...  [Read More]
Intro.918: New attack method can be used to track mobile devices that rely on MAC address randomization to protect privacy  [Read More]
Intro.919: Another fake bank notification spam has been spotted by our engineers and the sample we caught is a typical example of such email-based threats. The body of the letter, designed to mimic an official notification from a very popular bank in Britain, urgently tells the reader to check the attached file in order to verify 'terms and conditions', most likely for the purpose of a business transaction.Read more
Intro.920: We recently encountered a spam sample that purports itself to be a purchase order from IKEA, which is a famous furniture retailer founded in Sweden and features modern Scandanavian furniture. However, once unsuspecting users or legitimate IKEA customers open the attached .Read more
Intro.921: Users may find e-mails coming from a known antivirus company nothing to be surprised about, but alarms should definitely start ringing when the antivirus company mailing you isn't the one you're subscribed to - and that their mails are festooned with links to websites peddling Viagra.Our team of engineers recently found a spam mail making the rounds, masking itself as a legit mail coming from CA Technologies.Read more
Intro.922: In a bid to get users to click, cybercriminals turn to your trusted persons. We have seen spammed messages with vCard attachments, electronic business cards that contain personal information of a person such as name, address, phone number, email address, website and even audio clips.Read more
Intro.923: Pharmaceutical spam isn't necessarily a malicious type of spam, but there exists the potential for them to lead to malicious or scam sites, so we always advise users to keep clear of them. This time is no different, as we spotted a new batch of samples that purported themselves to be urgent notifications from sites of general interest, such as Facebook, Youtube and Instagram.Read more
Intro.924: Cybercriminals will always capitalize on the popular and the trusted, and this latest pharmacy spam campaign is no exception. In fact, it proves the theory in spades, as not only does it spoof popular social networking website email notifications such as Facebook and Instagram, it also spoofs iTunes, Google and Fedex! The mails, while obviously different in terms of which website they're spoofing, all link to the same online pharmacy website, one that seems to specialize in performance enhancement drugs.Read more
Intro.925: Trend Micro researchers spotted another spammed email messages purporting to be from popular social networking sites LinkedIn and MySpace. The mail from LinkedIn asks the users to click on a provided link in order to confirm their email address.Read more
Intro.926: A spammed message promoting something called the Google Accredited Pharmacy is seen in the wild. The said email message contains an image that shows a link.Read more
Intro.927: With Valentine's Day just around the corner, spammers are leveraging this event to lure users into fake online pharmacy websites. The bogus sites promote Valentine's day special offers on pharmacy-related products.Read more
Intro.928: Trend Micro uncovered bulk samples of spam that sell pharmaceutical products. The message is written in both French and English.Read more
Intro.929: Holiday-themed threats are a staple in today's threat landscape. In particular, users should be on the lookout for spammed messages that leverage popular events.Read more
Intro.930: Spammers are now leveraging popular website, Wikipedia to point users to pharmacy sites. TrendLabs engineers spotted spammed messages in plain text that contained a URL.Read more
Intro.931: Cybercriminals always capitalize on current events as well as holidays. Just recently, TrendLabs researchers spotted spammed messages that bore the subject, 'Delivery within USA 2-3 day !!.Read more

Intro.965: A new cryptocurrency-mining malware was uncovered targeting macOS systems: — OSX.CreativeUpdate Here's what you need to know.
Intro.966: Due to BEC’s evolving and treacherous nature, run-of-the-mill best practices and security solutions have become weak to withstand attacks. Find out how advanced solutions that utilize artificial intelligence and machine learning help in defending against BEC.
Intro.967: Security researchers uncovered a multi-stage attack chain that takes advantage of a design behavior in RTF files and a vulnerability in Microsoft Office (CVE-2017-8570) to deliver the Formbook RAT.
Intro.968: A new cryptocurrency-mining malware was uncovered targeting macOS systems: — OSX.CreativeUpdate Here's what you need to know.
Intro.969: Two remote access Trojans targeting Mac users are making headlines: Snake and Proton. Know more about their malicious tricks and how to mitigate them.
Intro.970: A MacOS ransomware, a disguised Venus Locker variant and other notable ransomware stories from February 16-24, 2017.
Intro.971: Cybercriminals known as the Skimer Group are reusing the malware they created to target ATMs seven years ago—posing a more sophisticated and advanced threat to banks and customers around the globe.
Intro.972: Microsoft is rolling out Office 2016 with an anti-macro malware feature. We tell you all about it and how to activate it.
Intro.973: KeRanger, believed to be the world's first ransomware specifically designed to infect OS X machines has been found piggybacking on a compromised installer of a BitTorrent client.
Intro.974: A new crypto-ransomware type called Locky has been discovered riding on document-based macros and using infection techniques borrowed from the notorious banking malware DRIDEX.
Intro.975: SMBs accounted for 45% of all incidents involving PoS malware in Q3 2015, but malware isn't the only thing that retailers have to worry about. PoS machines can be compromised even before they get installed.
Intro.976: It's been 20 years since the first macro malware was discovered in 1995. Here's how it evolved through the years.
Intro.977: Last month, a Latin American organized crime gang hacked over 14 ATMs in Malaysia, pilfering an estimated RM3mil (almost $1 million USD). While the incident only affected the banks that were hit, there are other threats that target ATM users as well.
Intro.978: Right on the heels of the Shellshock comes another threat that targets Mac users. Known as iWORM, this malware connects to a C&C; server, allowing it to perform actions ranging from information theft and file downloads to configuration changes.
Intro.979: Who did hack Macron? The obvious conclusion is Russia; because Russia would benefit most from a Le Pen victory. But the timing of the document leaks was far too late to benefit Le Pen, and would more likely benefit Macron.  [Read More]
Intro.980: NSA Director Admiral Mike Rogers said that Russia was behind the hack of French President-elect Emmanuel Macron's campaign team, and that US officials had informed France a cyber-attack was underway.  [Read More]
Intro.981: Russia-linked Turla cyberspies are apparently working on developing a Mac OS X version of their Snake malware  [Read More]
Intro.982: Machete cyberespionage group continues to target organizations in Spanish-speaking and other countries  [Read More]
Intro.983: Russia-linked threat group APT28 (aka Pawn Storm, Fancy Bear and Sofacy) created a Mac version of its X-Agent Trojan  [Read More]
Intro.984: Cyber espionage group linked to Iran uses Mac malware named MacDownloader to steal data from infected devices  [Read More]
Intro.985: Cybercriminals have been serving malicious advertisements on several high-profile websites in an effort to push shady software onto the computers of their visitors, regardless if they are Windows or OS X users, Cisco reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.986: The malware at the center of the 'Machete' cyber attacks is capable of a number of actions, including logging keystrokes, capturing audio and screenshots, taking photos from the victim's webcam and capturing geo-location data.  [Read More]
Intro.987: A variant of the Dok malware for Mac targets Swiss banking users in attacks that appear to be part of Operation Emmental  [Read More]
Intro.988: A malicious RTF (Rich Text Format) document has been persistently displaying an alert asking users to enable macros, Zscaler security researchers have discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.989: A malicious attack uses a multi-stage infection to deploy a tool capable of stealing passwords from various applications on the victim’s computer, Trustwave reports.  [Read More]
Intro.990: Maliciously modified copies of popular applications distributed via the MacUpdate site were observed installing crypto-mining malware on the users’ Macs.  [Read More]
Intro.991: Focused on mining Monero crypto-currency, a new botnet has managed to ensnare over half a million machines to date, most of which are believed to be servers.  [Read More]
Intro.992: MaMi is a new piece of malware designed to hijack DNS settings on infected macOS machines. Other capabilities present, but not active  [Read More]
Intro.993: An Ohio man was charged this week in a 16-count indictment for allegedly developing malware known as “FruitFly” and for infecting thousands of computers with it.  [Read More]
Intro.994: In an effort to boost the fight against malicious software, anti-malware company Avast this week announced the release of its retargetable machine-code decompiler as open source.  [Read More]
Intro.995: macOS-targeting HiddenLotus backdoor is using an innovative technique to disguise the fact that it is an executable in order to avoid alerting users on its execution.  [Read More]
Intro.996: A newly observed variant of the macOS-targeting Proton malware is spreading through a blog spoofing that of legitimate security company Symantec.  [Read More]
Intro.997: Hackers breach Eltima website and use it to deliver macOS RAT Proton via a trojanized version of Elmedia Player  [Read More]
Intro.998: Recently observed distribution campaigns featuring the Ursnif banking Trojan were using new malicious macro tactics for payload delivery  [Read More]
Intro.999: WikiLeaks publishes documents describing three tools used by the CIA to hack OS X and other POSIX systems  [Read More]
Intro.1000: A news website in Georgia delivers a new version of the old Mac Trojan dubbed Leverage to Safari users  [Read More]
Intro.1001: A variant of the Dok malware for Mac targets Swiss banking users in attacks that appear to be part of Operation Emmental  [Read More]
Intro.1002: Hot on the heels of MacRansom Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) comes the first malware-as-a-service (MaaS) targeting Mac users, offered for prices starting as low as free, AlienVault reveals.  [Read More]
Intro.1003: MacRansom is a newly discovered ransomware family targeting Mac users is using the Ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) distribution model and uses code copied from previous MacOS ransomware, Fortinet researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1004: Trend Micro has published details on a spam campaign it detected in late May that delivers malware by using PowerPoint files and mouseover events.  [Read More]
Intro.1005: A download mirror for the video converting tool HandBrake was recently compromised and configured to distribute a remote administration Trojan (RAT) for Mac computers.  [Read More]
Intro.1006: The Cerber ransomware is using new evasion techniques designed elude machine learning security solutions.  [Read More]
Intro.1007: Cybercriminals have been using a macro-enabled Word document that can be used to infect both macOS and Windows machines with malware.  [Read More]
Intro.1008: macOS users who had their systems infected with the FindZip ransomware can now use a decryption tool to restore their files without paying the ransom.  [Read More]
Intro.1009: A new remote access tool (RAT) targeting macOS machines currently advertised on underground markets is believed to be using an unpatched 0-day vulnerability to gain root access on target machines.  [Read More]
Intro.1010: Filecoder is a newly discovered ransomware targeting macOS that destroys encryption keys before sending them to its apparently inexperienced developer.  [Read More]
Intro.1011: Russia-linked threat group APT28 (aka Pawn Storm, Fancy Bear and Sofacy) created a Mac version of its X-Agent Trojan  [Read More]
Intro.1012: A recently discovered Microsoft Office loader uses malicious macros to drop multiple malware families, Palo Alto Networks security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1013: Malware that abuses macro-enabled Microsoft Office documents to spread is now targeting macOS users too.  [Read More]
Intro.1014: Cyber espionage group linked to Iran uses Mac malware named MacDownloader to steal data from infected devices  [Read More]
Intro.1015: Newly discovered Quimitchin malware has been found infecting Mac OS X systems, in what security experts consider to be "the first Mac malware of 2017."  [Read More]
Intro.1016: Malware designed to crash Mac OS machines is being delivered through drive-by downloads as part of a campaign designed to trick users into calling a fake tech support service.  [Read More]
Intro.1017: The destructive KillDisk malware previously associated with attacks targeting industrial firms, was recently observed infecting Linux machines as well, ESET security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1018: The Nymaim Trojan is now fingerprinting MAC addresses and comparing the targeted machine’s MAC address against a hardcoded list, which allows it to avoid virtual environments and thwart analysis tools.  [Read More]
Intro.1019: According McAfee, new malware samples in Q2 2016 totaled more than 40 million, which is the second highest quarterly figure ever recorded.  [Read More]
Intro.1020: The Locky ransomware has switched back to the distribution method of Office documents with malicious macros, FireEye researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1021: Malware operators can hide the use of malicious macros to distribute malware by simply renaming the offending Office documents, Cisco researchers reveal.  [Read More]
Intro.1022: New developments in machine learning (ML), artificial intelligence (AI), and cognitive computing (CC) can play an important role in cyber security.  [Read More]
Intro.1023: A new Mac OS X piece of malware was designed to steal the content of the keychain and to establish permanent backdoor access to the infected system, ESET security researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1024: Malware that masquerades as legitimate software application called EasyDoc Converter is actually a malicious backdoor that provides attackers with full access to a compromised Mac system.  [Read More]
Intro.1025: A series of attacks carried out against banks in the Middle East in early May were using Macros and unique PowerShell scripts that are not commonly seen in crimeware campaigns, researchers at FireEye warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1026: Macro malware has recently returned to focus and is evolving, courtesy of tricks designed to better keep the malicious code hidden, Microsoft warns.  [Read More]
Intro.1027: A new fileless ransomware family has been discovered, which abuses Windows’ PowerShell for nefarious activities, a novel approach to ransomware, Carbon Black researchers warn.  [Read More]
Intro.1028: A new piece of malware dubbed PowerSniff abuses macros and PowerShell in semi-targeted attacks aimed at the U.S. and Europe  [Read More]
Intro.1029: Dridex and Locky macro malware families are now using Form object in macros to obfuscate their malicious code.  [Read More]
Intro.1030: Macro malware, one of the most successful threats in the 1990s, has returned to focus in the form of persistent threats targeting organizations, Intel Security reports.  [Read More]
Intro.1031: The number of Mac OS X systems infected with malware during the first nine months of 2015 is seven times higher than in all of 2014, Symantec reports.  [Read More]
Intro.1032: The Vawtrak banking malware now leverages macros and the Windows PowerShell scripting tool to infect computers, Trend Micro reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.1033: Google's Macintosh Operations Team announced last week the availability of the source code for "Santa," a tool designed for whitelisting and blacklisting binaries on Apple's Mac OS X operating systems.  [Read More]
Intro.1034: The Rovnix Trojan has started leveraging macros embedded in innocent-looking Microsoft Word documents to infect computers, researchers at Trend Micro reported.  [Read More]
Intro.1035: Researchers at Palo Alto Networks identified a piece of malware called WireLurker that was designed to target Mac OS X and iOS users. Experts believe WireLurker once again shows that Apple devices are not immune to malware.  [Read More]
Intro.1036: Researchers at Palo Alto Networks have uncovered a new piece of malware designed to target devices running Apple's OS X and iOS operating systems and might have been installed by hundreds of thousands of users.  [Read More]
Intro.1037: A new piece of malware (Mac.BackDoor.iWorm) has infected thousands of Mac OS X devices and uses Reddit to get a list of command and control (C&C) servers.  [Read More]
Intro.1038: Cybercriminals have been serving malicious advertisements on several high-profile websites in an effort to push shady software onto the computers of their visitors, regardless if they are Windows or OS X users, Cisco reported on Monday.  [Read More]
Intro.1039: A Windows backdoor used in numerous attacks by a certain threat group has been ported to Mac OS X and fitted with new features, researchers at FireEye reported.  [Read More]
Intro.1040: Triumfant's new endpoint security agent for Mac OS provides real-time detection and automatic remediation of malware and other sophisticated attacks occurring in-memory or on a hard drive.  [Read More]
Intro.1041: VirusTotal, the popular service that lets users analyze suspicious files and URLs to help facilitate the detection of malware, has launched a Mac OS X version of its VirusTotal Uploader utility.  [Read More]
Intro.1042: Intego, a provider of security products designed exclusively for Mac OS, introduced its latest product line, including VirusBarrier X8 and NetBarrier X8.  [Read More]
Intro.1043: Researchers from Kaspersky Lab have uncovered a new malware that has the ability to infect systems running Windows, Mac OS X, and Linux and launch DDoS attacks from any infected devices.  [Read More]
Intro.1044: Bit9, announced an enterprise-class security solution for Mac OS X that continuously monitors and records all activity on desktops, laptops and servers while working to stop targeted and advanced attacks.  [Read More]
Intro.1045: Researchers found malware which acts as a backdoor for Mac OS X on a computer belonging to an activist attending the Oslo Freedom Forum this week.  [Read More]
Intro.1046: Researchers at ESET have discovered a Trojan that initially focused on Windows users, but appears to be changing direction and now targeting Mac OS X users.  [Read More]
Intro.1047: While the motivation for the recent cyber-attacks against Korean organizations remains unclear, researchers have identified the malware used as a data-wiping Trojan.  [Read More]
Intro.1048: Mac security firm Intego has discovered a new type of malware for OS X, which will pose a bit of a problem when it comes to protection, given its use of Open SSH.  [Read More]
Intro.1049: Researchers have observed a recent spike in attacks against the Uyghur community to monitor their email and chat activities, according AlientVault and Kaspersky Lab.  [Read More]
Intro.1050: Tibetan activists are being targeted by a new variant of the Imuler (Revir) Trojan that was discovered in September. The attack is launched via email, and uses images of other pro-Tibetan groups as bait in order to encourage the victim into opening files.  [Read More]
Intro.1051: Anti-Virus firm Dr. Web has discovered another family of Mac-based malware that targets passwords. In addition to Mac OS X, this malware also targets Linux installations.  [Read More]
Intro.1052: Symantec malware researchers discovered that the JAR file that is used by Crisis to infect a given system has an additional payload for Windows, and may be the first malware that attempts to spread onto a virtual machine.  [Read More]
Intro.1053: New features in the Alpha++ release of CrowdRE include Linux and Mac versions of the plugin, as well as granular sharing controls and "Karma" ratings within the platform.  [Read More]
Intro.1054: ThreatMetrix, published a report on the Crisis Trojan that breaks the code down, and examines the internals of the latest threat targeting Mac OS X users.  [Read More]
Intro.1055: On Tuesday, a new type of malware was discovered that targets Apple’s Mac OS X. Called Crisis, the Trojan creates a backdoor on an infected Mac as long as it runs OS X version 10.6 or 10.7.  [Read More]
Intro.1056: If allowed to run, a malicious Java applet checks the user's operating system and delivers a payload customized for that platform, whether it's Windows, Mac OS X, or Linux.  [Read More]
Intro.1057: Researchers from Russian security firm Kaspersky Lab today said they have discovered a new APT campaign that is using a new Mac OS X backdoor variant targeted at Uyghur activists.  [Read More]
Intro.1058: Version 11.3 of Adobe’s Flash Player, due in June, will provide the same silent update feature currently available to Windows users to those running OS X. In addition, Adobe will also offer a new security enhancement to Firefox called protected mode.  [Read More]
Intro.1059: Microsoft researchers have discovered new malware targeting the Mac, but unlike Flashback, this one is targeting a flaw in Office for Mac that was patched years ago.  [Read More]
Intro.1060: Once SabPub is installed on a Mac, it will connect to a C&C and wait for instructions. To have a look at what happens after, Kaspersky installed SabPub on a test system and let it run.  [Read More]
Intro.1061: The malware, known as SabPub, has been spotted spreading through malicious Microsoft Word documents exploiting the same Java vulnerability targeted by the now-notorious Flashback Trojan.  [Read More]
Intro.1062: Security researchers at Kaspersky Lab and Intego have released free tools to help Mac users infected with the Flashback Trojan clean their computers.  [Read More]
Intro.1063: Security researchers say the Flashback malware hitting Mac OS X machines has built a powerful botnet of more than 550,000 computers.  [Read More]
Intro.1064: If exploited, the Mac malware could drop additional malicious payloads, or modify targeted websites in order to bombard a user with annoying ads – which earn money for the attackers.  [Read More]
Intro.1065: The Trojan, named “Mac Control” by its authors, executes when the system starts, and will established a connection to the C&C in order to wait for commands. Investigation into the malware itself shows it has the ability to allow remote shells, as well as the ability to send, receive, and delete files.  [Read More]
Intro.1066: On Friday, Intego reported that a new variant of Flashback is targeting passwords and as a byproduct of infection, Flashback is crashing several notable applications.  [Read More]
Intro.1067: A Trojan targeting Mac OS X, named Flashback by some vendors, is disabling the XProtect component of Apple’s operating system. The latest variant of the Fashback will disable XProtect’s automatic update features, preventing new detections from being installed to the infected host.  [Read More]

Intro.1249: Another fake bank notification spam has been spotted by our engineers and the sample we caught is a typical example of such email-based threats. The body of the letter, designed to mimic an official notification from a very popular bank in Britain, urgently tells the reader to check the attached file in order to verify 'terms and conditions', most likely for the purpose of a business transaction.Read more
Intro.1250: We recently encountered a spam sample that purports itself to be a purchase order from IKEA, which is a famous furniture retailer founded in Sweden and features modern Scandanavian furniture. However, once unsuspecting users or legitimate IKEA customers open the attached .Read more
Intro.1251: Users may find e-mails coming from a known antivirus company nothing to be surprised about, but alarms should definitely start ringing when the antivirus company mailing you isn't the one you're subscribed to - and that their mails are festooned with links to websites peddling Viagra.Our team of engineers recently found a spam mail making the rounds, masking itself as a legit mail coming from CA Technologies.Read more
Intro.1252: In a bid to get users to click, cybercriminals turn to your trusted persons. We have seen spammed messages with vCard attachments, electronic business cards that contain personal information of a person such as name, address, phone number, email address, website and even audio clips.Read more
Intro.1253: Pharmaceutical spam isn't necessarily a malicious type of spam, but there exists the potential for them to lead to malicious or scam sites, so we always advise users to keep clear of them. This time is no different, as we spotted a new batch of samples that purported themselves to be urgent notifications from sites of general interest, such as Facebook, Youtube and Instagram.Read more
Intro.1254: Cybercriminals will always capitalize on the popular and the trusted, and this latest pharmacy spam campaign is no exception. In fact, it proves the theory in spades, as not only does it spoof popular social networking website email notifications such as Facebook and Instagram, it also spoofs iTunes, Google and Fedex! The mails, while obviously different in terms of which website they're spoofing, all link to the same online pharmacy website, one that seems to specialize in performance enhancement drugs.Read more
Intro.1255: Trend Micro researchers spotted another spammed email messages purporting to be from popular social networking sites LinkedIn and MySpace. The mail from LinkedIn asks the users to click on a provided link in order to confirm their email address.Read more
Intro.1256: A spammed message promoting something called the Google Accredited Pharmacy is seen in the wild. The said email message contains an image that shows a link.Read more

Intro.1258: Trend Micro uncovered bulk samples of spam that sell pharmaceutical products. The message is written in both French and English.Read more
Intro.1259: Holiday-themed threats are a staple in today's threat landscape. In particular, users should be on the lookout for spammed messages that leverage popular events.Read more

The body of the letter, designed to mimic an official notification from a very popular bank in Britain, urgently tells the reader to check the attached file in order to verify 'terms and conditions', most likely for the purpose of a business transaction.Read more
Intro.1428: We recently encountered a spam sample that purports itself to be a purchase order from IKEA, which is a famous furniture retailer founded in Sweden and features modern Scandanavian furniture. However, once unsuspecting users or legitimate IKEA customers open the attached .Read more

Intro.1430: In a bid to get users to click, cybercriminals turn to your trusted persons. We have seen spammed messages with vCard attachments, electronic business cards that contain personal information of a person such as name, address, phone number, email address, website and even audio clips.Read more
Intro.1431: Pharmaceutical spam isn't necessarily a malicious type of spam, but there exists the potential for them to lead to malicious or scam sites, so we always advise users to keep clear of them. This time is no different, as we spotted a new batch of samples that purported themselves to be urgent notifications from sites of general interest, such as Facebook, Youtube and Instagram.Read more
Intro.1432: Cybercriminals will always capitalize on the popular and the trusted, and this latest pharmacy spam campaign is no exception. In fact, it proves the theory in spades, as not only does it spoof popular social networking website email notifications such as Facebook and Instagram, it also spoofs iTunes, Google and Fedex! The mails, while obviously different in terms of which website they're spoofing, all link to the same online pharmacy website, one that seems to specialize in performance enhancement drugs.Read more
